TEXT.English: [TAB]The required education for a child of a noble family included writing, religious instruction, physical education, and training in the courtly arts. A noble child would begin attending school between the ages of five and seven years of age. The hammozgar, or teacher would instract him in writing and memorization of the Zoroastrian holy scriptures, as well as to recite the yasts and hold the Barsom, or sacred bundle, at a very early age. As well he would be versed in astrology, literature, writing and the law. He would also be trained in the etiquette of the court, ceremonies, how to treat women, gardening, and singing. He would play games such as chess and Backgammon. He would further be trained in horsemanship, hunting, archery, wrestling, polo, and the military arts, with his training and studies completed by the age of fifteen.
